tree_site_notes: ICHmw2. Tree sits on valley bottom with multiple wildlife cavities. FCs with >10% diameter change. Located 80m from S1 stream.
ICHmw2. Multiple Forks and crooks present. East aspect.

access_notes: From Jaffray or Elko drive down to Kikomun Creek Prov. Park.  Take Teepee Cr Rd. west across Koocanusa Lake, past the campground/boat access. Then head south on Caven Cr FSR (starting at 15.5 km).  At 32.5 km turn left onto Bloom FSR, at 42.5 turn right onto Middle Bloom and park just past the 45 km sign.  It is a short hike down to the creek through ~50 yr old Lodgepole pine second growth.
tree_site_notes:
This tree has some scorch at the bottom, but is otherwise quite intact.  Remnants of a whorl of large branches is evident at about 6m up.  Two other larch trees are within 5-6m of this one, forming quite a trio!  The two largest of the three are within 5m of a tributary to Bloom Creek.  The other large larch (128cm DBH) is leaning downstream and would be close to 55m if growing straight up. The smaller (~1m) larch has a broken top, totald height is about 35m.  Another large larch lies toppled over the creek, making a natural bridge just upstream.
A proposed bridge location and road centre line is marked out about 20m upstream and upslope from the two closer trees of the trio.  
The surrounding riparian area contains a range of species - spruce, balsam, cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir but all the largest trees are western larch up and down the creek for about 100m, with large live trees, short and tall snags, and down trees. Most of these larch are in the 80cm diam range.

access_notes: The River Rd. FSR follows along the east side of the Elk River opposite side from highway 3. The area between the CPR tracks and the river has many hidden cottonwoods to be discovered.
tree_site_notes: The famed Morrissey Ancient Cottonwood site has many fine trees, so it is only to be expected that some other big cottonwoods are present in other Elk river locations. This big old age beaten tree has many broken limbs all strewn about at its base, but otherwise seems healthy.

access_notes: The City sewage treatment lagoons is your interim destination. Follow Cokato south out of Fernie, until reaching Thompson Rd., turn right, cross railway tracks, continue until end of the road. This is sometimes a closed gate. If open, drive to lagoons chainlink fence, and follow it west toward the river. The Cokato Forgotten Forest is all along the Elk River.
tree_site_notes: A very interesting forest composition with some very old +400 year old trees intermixed with the 120 year old fire gen. trees.

access_notes: Skiing is the easiest way to find this tree as signs and ski area maps will direct you there. If accessing in the summer, a good approach is to come up the Gorby Trail from Mt. Fernie Provincial Park and keep on following the summer access roads into Cedar Bowl. This big spruce is up in this bowl.
tree_site_notes: Tree does not have much remaining stature, as the top has been annihilated by either avalanches, lightning or a combination of both. Diameter is very significant.

access_notes: From Island Lake Lodge follow trail signage to Spineback Trail. In the lower meadows, before the trail begins its descent into the Three Bears peaks, a display of mature Engelmann spruce line the corridor. The noted tree is right beside the trail, and is an outstanding sight.
tree_site_notes: Having measured up quite a few Engelmann Spruce, I would have to sy this is the showiest of the bunch.

access_notes: The locally celebrated Corn Creek Cedar is right beside this tree. Turn south from Highway 3 into West Creston, and carry on through the Creston Wildlife Management Area, until the first bridge crossing, Corn Creek has a small parking area, a short walk upstream and the Cedar and Grand Fir are hanging out together here.
tree_site_notes: Not being that familiar with grand fir trees where I live, it is a real treat to see their shiny glossy wide spread needles on display in the forest.

access_notes: Hembrie Ridge is well known for its well established Douglas-fir and ponderosa pines. The Hembrie Mountain Road, accessed off of the Princeton / Summerland Road at approx. 9 km from town, is a good starting point to explore these expansive big tree strewn hillsides.
tree_site_notes: In search of the fabled Hembrie Ridge Fir referenced in the BC Big Tree Registry, it quickly became revealed that there were lots of Douglas fir and Ponderosas scattered throughout this expansive ridgeline. The tree was a very nice find, on a warmed up southwest facing slope.

access_notes: Daladon Road accesses a new subdivision development above the Logan Lake townsite. The grouping of these veteran trees is  located by finding the only opening between some houses (utility /park access corridor) on this road, and head downhill, where a small pond with a bit of a trail network winds about some old boy Dougs.
tree_site_notes: Introduced to this site by long-time environmental advocate Bert Parkes, the trees he had tagged with dimensions 20 years previous had long since faded, but Bert and the trees havent.

access_notes: Larch Hills Nordic area is accessed from the Grandview Bench Road, and then follow signage up gravel roads for 8 km to the day lodge. The big trees are a further 5 km up the Larch Hills FSR, on the aptly named Big Tree Alley.
tree_site_notes: This giant Douglas-fir is right at the edge of a big logging block, and right beside the road. Appears lonely with all of its brethren having been sacrificed to the saw.

access_notes: Highway 16 from McBride to Prince George is devoid of settlements, unless you travel a few km down to the Fraser River, then there are a few hardy souls eeking a living. Dome Creek is the only settlement in the vicinity of this tree. Spied right from the highway to the northeast of the Ptarmigan Creek bridge.
tree_site_notes: Another one of the amazing trees hiding out in this frontier. This Douglas-fir has been visited by timber cruisers in the past, as the paint marks on the tree indicate. But the recent Provincial Park designation should keep it safe for a while.

access_notes: There is a trail called Old Stumpy that is part of the Elk Valley / Transcanada Trail. It heads north out of Fernie, and about 1 km along a lone Lodgepole Pine stands beside the BC Hydro right of way.
tree_site_notes: This Lodgepole Pine likely regenerated after the 1908 Fernie fire, and has managed to put on some extra growth as a result of its southern exposure, spring fed water source, and generally nice view.

access_notes: The Below the Gods Trail is accessed in the Smallwood Creek area. Turn off of Highway 3a onto Beasley Road, then make the first quick right onto Queen Victoria St. This road transitions into the Smallwood FSR. There are too many junctions to describe, so utilize Trailforks to find this trail.
tree_site_notes: Having been given a tip about the big trees along this trail, the mixture of cedar and hemlock is a common site in this region. The presence of sub-surface water where this big hemlock is growing, has obviously had a positive influence on its growth. This is a Skookum tree.

access_notes: The small settlement of Ferguson is accessed from Highway 31 near Trout Lake. The gravel road climbs up beside the Lardeau River where you will come to a wye, turn right onto the Alpha FSR and drive about 500 m, where on the right a myriad of trails lead down towards the river. The big hemlock is hiding down in the wetness with a bunch of spruce and cedars.
tree_site_notes: There are quite a few big hemlocks lurking in this forest. This particular tree was the largest found and over 400 years old.

access_notes: Davis Creek Trail is accessed from Highway 31 to the north of Kaslo, near the village of Lardeau. The Provincial Park campground is a good place to park your vehicle, and then begin the steep climb up to the Rim. The forest changes to Larch, then into a cedar/hemlock as the ground flattens out a bit. Water does not seem to know where to run, and the ground is wet everywhere. The trail ends at Fishhook Lake, with big trees to be found all around.
tree_site_notes: This mighty hemlock was very close to the trail, with a lot of the trees having been given appreciative names. This guy is Hemi

access_notes: The Princeton Kamloops Highway 5A climbs up from Merritt towards Princeton. On the right about  5 km from town is the Kane Valley Road. Follow this gravel road until reaching the Harmon Lake Rec site. The big Ponderosa Pine is not too much further along and is visible from the road.
tree_site_notes: With its candelabra of branches spreading out in all directions, this tree seems like it should have a pride of lions hanging out with it.

access_notes: Kalamalka Provincial Park in Coldstream is well signed, so follow signage to the last parking lot. From here head up the Corral Trail to Cougar Cairn junction and then continue up the Lookout Trail. The tree is on the escarpment overlooking the lake.
tree_site_notes: This tree seems to be taking advantage of its promentory above Kalamalka Lake. One of the lower branches extended out over 5 m.

access_notes: Enderby Bluffs Trail is well signed, directing you to a trailhead parking area. The trail climbs up through a mixed juvenile forest before alighting onto a rocky boulder strewn bench. There were quite a few veteran trees (larch, spruce, cedar) and a surprise showing of this ponderosa pine very close to the trail.
tree_site_notes: The big Ponderosa seems to be one of the very few trees of this species. Showing signs of fire scarred bark this veteran just outlasted the rest of the forest.

access_notes: Little Lost Lake trail is accessed off of Highway 16, where a precariously approached pull-out is the parking area. A few kms east of Tete Jaune Cache you will see a signed trailhead and pull-out on the right. The trail climbs steeply until you get closer to the lake. There is a loop walk around the lake. This is where this impressive birch tree was found.
tree_site_notes: Looking around and measuring up some of the big Douglas-fir trees that are growing around the lake, we stumbled upon one of the largest and most beautiful paper birches I have ever seen. Very tall, very healthy, and with a spectacular peeling bark show.

access_notes: Enderby Bluffs Trail is well signed, directing you to a trailhead parking area. The trail ascends for about 8 km, then daylights onto the crest of the imposing bluffs. There are a few Rocky Mountain Junipers along this ridgeline, with a couple of the larger ones growing very close to the edge and right near the end of the trail
tree_site_notes: When someone tells you about a special tree, and even shows you a photo, it is time to venture out to find it. Curious how this tree compared to the champion in the Standard Hills, I had to see for myself. A long hike on a very hot day, almost had us turning around prematurely, luckily we mustered up some extra gusto, and not too much further on reside these unique, full sized junipers. It would be interesting to know how old they are?

access_notes: Located at Fernie Alpine Resort, a person could ride the Elk Chair up (summer or winter) then walk up the summer road into the Lizard Bowl, where it wraps around to the top of the Ballet Run. Hidden in the alder behind a big larch tree is the subalpine fir.
tree_site_notes: There are many vey old subalpine fir growing in the Lizard Range. This particular tree has the benefit of being on a knob that is not subject to the many avalanches that course down either side. Also the big larch seems to have also afforded some protection. This tree is well hidden, and it is not until you climb underneath its branches to you gain the appreciation for how massive it is.

access_notes: Located on Fernie Alpine Resort property on the edge of a logging block known locally as Charlies clearcut. Park at Lot 4 where the x-country ski trailhead is located, take the left trail going downhill. When you come to the first fork, head south into the cut-block. Roaming around in here you might find the tree.
tree_site_notes: A trembling aspen of this size loses its identity somewhat, as the bark on the lower trunk begins to resemble that of a cottonwood. Unmistakable are the shiny white branches above, and the characteristic branch configuration of the aspen.

access_notes: Wallys Follies is an obscure ski run at Fernie Alpine Resort. It is most easily accessed in the winter when skiing. If interested in visiting this site in summer, the easiest approach would be to walk up Gorby Trail from the Mt Fernie Provincial Park to where it meets Red Tree Road. Follow the road to the right until you come to the Snakebite Trail (also many big larches) sign on the right, but turn left and head up into the bush where an assortment of very large larch and cedar trees are gathered.
tree_site_notes: A western larch tree of this height stands out above the surrounding forest canopy. I was looking for a big cedar, which I found, but was pleasantly surprised to come across this old larch, with its battle scarred base and stout trunk, it was a very nice sight.

access_notes: The Big Larch Trail is accessed from a roadside pull-out that is on the right a few km north of Hills on Highway 6. A signed trailhead directs you up a de-commissioned logging road. At the 3rd switchback an old skid trail heads off to the south, where you will cross a small creek. The big larches are just above on the edge of a fairly recently logged area.
tree_site_notes: Wow!, what a tree. A friend of mine from Rosebery sent me a photo of himself under a big larch. He said it was over 5  in diameter. While not quite making that size, this is an outstanding trees as the photos reveal.

access_notes: Giveout Creek FSR is located above and to the south of Nelson where a right turn just past the Waldorf School turn-off leads up and up for about 8 km. The Bears Den trail is best referenced on Trailforks to locate where to head up.
tree_site_notes: In awe about the big cedars and hemlocks that have man-made biking structures winding up and over some wild terrain, these big larches could go by un-noticed. The tree is over 400 years old, and it appears that it will be around for a long time yet.

access_notes: Gilnockie Provincial Park and Ecological Reserve are a long ways from anywhere. Located close to the US border between Grasmere and Yahk, this 100 km section of wilderness (minus all the logging blocks) is accessed from Caven Creek FSR, Bloom Creek FSR, and Ward Creek FSR. Gilnockie Creek is best accessed by driving 2.3 km west of the Yahk River bridge, and then bushwhacking down to the creek along the edge of a clearcut. Many superb larch specimens reside along the creek.
tree_site_notes: Not often a grouping of veteran western larches is encountered. This assembly of massive trees residing on a bench above Gilnockie Creek supports quite a display of greatness. The larch is an amazing 517 years old.

access_notes: Follow the signage from Nakusp to the Kuskanax Creek Hot Springs. From the parking lot a well signed trail to the creek and then a left at the wye to Kimbol Lake . Climbing up past the old hot springs source to a rest bench, the western white pine is on the slope down towards the creek, and visible from the bench.
tree_site_notes: Western white pines, with their towering trunks, special elongated cones, and soft needles, I would describe as a friendly tree. This particular tree is no different. Special in every way.

access_notes: Larch Hills Nordic area is accessed from the Grandview Bench Road, and then follow signage up gravel roads for 8 km to the day lodge. A further 5 km up the Larch Hills FSR, and you will come to the White Pine Walk. A nice loop through some boggy ground with a great selection of big trees to ogle over. The big western white pine is a short distance in on this trail.
tree_site_notes: When you see a western white pine of this magnitude it goes off the Richter scale. Towering straight up into the forest canopy, this tree is winning the reach for the light game.

access_notes: From Highway 3 when travelling west from Creston, and right before the yellow avalanche closure gate is a large pull-out parking area on your left, where some unobtrusive trail signs are attached to the trees. Situated quite high up on the trees so as to not disappear as the snow pack gets deeper. A trail heads down to where it crosses Summit Creek, and then a loop configuration allows you to chose your direction on the 1.3 km route. I like to walk it both ways, as new delights are revealed every time.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlocks of this enormity are not that common, generally succumbing to old age, rot, blowdown, or casual chainsaw death. The sheltered high elevation environment seems well suited for this big tree. This is the biggest tree found in this grove, but there are likely some larger ones to be found if getting off trail is your thing.

access_notes: A long drive on Highway 16 from McBride or PG will land you at the Ancient Forest PP parking lot. The big trees line the 3.4 km boardwalk.
tree_site_notes: Estimated to be 1800 years old, The Big Tree as the name suggests is just that. One of, if not the chubbiest cedars in B.C.s Interior.

access_notes: A long drive on Highway 16 from McBride or PG will land you at the Ancient Forest PP parking lot. The big trees line the 3.4 km boardwalk.
tree_site_notes: Treebeard, from the famed Tolkien Ents, has long pendulous branches reaching almost to the forest floor. Seemingly looking to get another anchor onto the ground.

access_notes: A long drive on Highway 16 from McBride or PG will land you at the Ancient Forest PP parking lot. The big trees line the 3.4 km boardwalk.
tree_site_notes: The Radius Tree has been heavily trafficked, and now has a protective fence around it to protect its roots. The buttressed base of this tree is amazing.

access_notes: A long drive on Highway 16 from McBride or PG will land you at the Ancient Forest PP parking lot. The big trees line the 3.4 km boardwalk.
tree_site_notes: This tree is located a little way off of the boardwalk. Its stout columnar trunk stood out in the jungle of devils club, and lured me humbly over to take its measurements.

access_notes: The turn off to the Cedar Grove Trail is 10 km from Highway 23.  A well signed forestry road to the left is followed for 5.5 km to the trailhead. The gravel road is quite rough and rocky, but is navigable with a 2 wheel drive vehicle. On the way up, there is a wye that is un-signed, so attention should be paid here to get where you want to go. The right branch is your direction.
tree_site_notes: This triple trunked cedar is a very solid looking tree. With black gooseberry trailing around at its base, it seemed well accompanied to put on a few more years growth.

access_notes: The Staubert Lake Cedars are tucked away beside the Trout Lake highway, and are easily accessed. A stylish wood  carved sign alerts you to the trailhead, where a small pull-out beside the road provides parking for a few vehicles.
tree_site_notes: This is the first tree encountered as you enter this enchanting grove. Spread out on the Beaton River /Poulman Creek floodplain, there are many spectacular trees, however the entry sentinel, with its own viewing chair is outstanding.

access_notes: The Staubert Lake Cedars are tucked away beside the Trout Lake highway, and are easily accessed. A stylish wood  carved sign alerts you to the trailhead, where a small pull-out beside the road provides parking for a few vehicles.
tree_site_notes: The #29 tree is located near the old homestead, and has a 29 tag on it. I think this might indicate 29 ft in circumference before it put on a bit more girth?

access_notes: The trail is accessed from the 2nd Island Lake parking lot in summer. Follow the Old Growth Trail to the Cabin Ridge junction (signed). Trail descends down to Lizard Creek, where a sometimes tenuous crossing is required. This big Cedar is just up the trail aways, but not right beside the trail.
tree_site_notes: A handsome twin trunk dominates this trees appearance. Whether it has inosculated, or just grew this way will never be known.

access_notes: The trail is accessed from the 2nd Island Lake parking lot in summer. Follow the Old Growth Trail to the Cabin Ridge junction (signed). Trail descends down to Lizard Creek, where a sometimes tenuous crossing is required. This big Cedar is just up the trail aways, but not right beside the trail.
tree_site_notes: Located right beside the trail, with a big burl overhanging you as you pass by, it is difficult to miss. The added Grizzly handle is because this game trail is the grizzly bears path when it traverses from Hunter Bowl to Cabin Bowl.

access_notes: Easily accessible, this tree can be found by driving on West Creston Road, just off Highway 3. At approximately 4.7 km you will come to a bridge that crosses Corn Creek. A small pullout just before the bridge, is the parking spot.
tree_site_notes: Standing alone beside Corn Creek this tree is very visible, and the area around the tree has been heavily visited. A view from the other side of the creek is worthwhile.

access_notes: The Gorby Trail is accessed from Mount Fernie Park Road off of  Highway 3. Drive to parking lot past campground, trailhead with aluminum bridge crossing Lizard Creek. Follow signage to Magic Grove.
tree_site_notes: The Magic Grove has some of the finest cedars in the Fernie area. The big tree is joined by some other enormous beauties, all clustered together to make a sheltered setting.

access_notes: Drive north up the Duncan FSR to the top of the lake. Cross Duncan River bridge, and look for road to left. Gate is sometimes closed, but walking in a couple of km will land you in this great forest collection on both sides of the road. The further you go, the bigger the trees get.
tree_site_notes: Sampled tree was on the west side of the road, standing amongst some grizzly bear chewed skunk baggage, and thick alder.

access_notes: The Island Lake lodge access road winds up through spectacular old-growth. Just find a place to park and explore.
tree_site_notes: With its buttressed roots dipping into the small stream at its base, it has a big foot look. Tree has a 6m dead spire.

access_notes: Davis Creek/Fishhook Lake trail is a steep hike, that starts at the Davis Creek Provincial Park campground in Lardeau.
tree_site_notes: Located close to Fishhook Lake this is one of many very large cedars and hemlocks that line the trail.

access_notes: Accessed from Highway 1 east of Sicamous, the Yard Creek P.P. Campground in Malakwa is well signed. The Eagle River Nature Park is located on the north side of the highway, and has a great little trail through some impressive forest.
tree_site_notes: The Cedar Sister is located in the 3rd grove along the trail, and is a beautiful tree. Nestled in amongst some other sisters, her bark shines, and her long limbs seep down for embraces.

access_notes: The Rail Trail leads out from the Island Lake lodge 1st parking lot. Follow trail until it comes into a meadow area. The tree is located to your left towards Lizard Creek.
tree_site_notes: The three upper trunks of this tree appear to have originated from one bole, creating its significant girth.

access_notes: From Highway 16, a  high bridge crosses over the Goat River. A rest area on the west side of the bridge is the parking area. The rough trail is on the south side of the highway, and continues for 8 km following up the Goat River.
tree_site_notes: The further you go up the valley the bigger the tree keep getting.

access_notes: Tree is located in the Duncan/Lardeau Flats Conservation Area.  Where the Duncan and Lardeau River converge at the north end of Kootenay Lake the delta flats provide an important habitat for: well everything. Access is at a signed, small gated pull-out just to the south of Meadow Creek.
tree_site_notes: The long branches of this tree hide its magnificence. Due to the open space afforded, this tree has taken full advantage of its surroundings, or lack thereof.

access_notes: Orca Road is an old skid trail that traverses at the base of the Lizard Range. A bridge crossing Lizard Creek, just upstream of the sawdust pile meadow in Cedar Valley is the trailhead.
tree_site_notes: Taking the time to grow lichen on your bark is a cooperative effort. This epiphyte and big cedar have done a good job, and the crop shows.

access_notes: Orca Road is an old skid trail that traverses at the base of the Lizard Range. A bridge crossing Lizard Creek, just upstream of the sawdust pile meadow in Cedar Valley is the trailhead. This tree is located on the downside of the road about 750 m after crossing the creek.
tree_site_notes: The Whale is a massive beast. With its wall of wood confronting you in the dark ocean of this forest. It gets its name from the Orca Rock peak whose fin sticks out of the sea of powder above, and is visible on the many horizons of the Lizard Range.

access_notes: From Highway 3, when travelling west from Creston over Kootenay Pass, a parking area on the left just before the avalanche road closure gate is the trailhead.
tree_site_notes: The tree in Ralphs Grove is just one of many amazing trees nestled in the sheltered hollow of Summit Creek. This tree stands out, as it is definitely the largest cedar that is visible from the trail.

access_notes: Follow the Sugar Lake FSR for 40 + kms until reaching Shuswap Falls Creek spur. The Ecological Reserve is on the opposite (river) side of the road. The tree is located on the flat benched area near the river.
tree_site_notes: A primeval setting, that appears ver coastal. The big limby tree has its own signature look with branches extending to touch the ground creating a sheltered cone at its base.

access_notes: Located beside the hydro transmission right of way clearing that crosses over the Elk River just upstream of where Morrissey Creek ties into the river.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a heavy lean and thickly covered in Gold Dust lichen.  Old Yeller is located in a wonderful setting amongst many very large cedars, cottonwoods, and the Jeffy Dougy fir.

access_notes: The trailhead for the Lazy Lizard is located at Island Lake Lodges 1st parking lot. The tree is about 4 km up the trail.
tree_site_notes: There are many large cedars that stud this trail. The sampled tree is off to the side aways, and is quite obscured by its very long branches that extend right into the surrounding alder and devils club.

access_notes: Orca Road is an old skid trail that traverses at the base of the Lizard Range. A bridge crossing Lizard Creek, just upstream of the sawdust pile meadow in Cedar Valley is the trailhead. This tree is located in a cedar studded opening once you have bushwhacked up past where the old logging was done early in the 1900s
tree_site_notes: Mother of Pearl, as the name implies, is  a significantly larger tree amongst the other meagre giants.

access_notes: Driving north on the Trout Lake Highway (gravel) from Meadow Creek, a small settlement of Poplar Creek is reached. At Rapid Creek, a well signed trailhead is positioned to direct you to the trail.
tree_site_notes: Standing in the expansive floodplain of the Lardeau River this huge tree is the first one to greet you when you enter the forest.

access_notes: Heading west from Creston on Highway 3 a parking lot on the right, just before the Summit Creek bridge is the starting point.
tree_site_notes: The Kootenay River has flooded these lowlands repeatedly over the lifespan of these big cedars that now languish in the well maintained grasses of a once established campground. The tree is estimated to be over 800 years.

access_notes: The paved Mica Creek highway travels for 100 km north of Revelstoke. Downie Creek is one of the major drainages that connect to Revelstoke Lake (see Columbia River). The tree is visible from the highway just before the Downie Creek bridge.
tree_site_notes: With a highway on one side, a logging road on the other, this grove is pinched in just above the Downie River escarpment. A very jungly approach is required to access from the highway. From the logging spur above is much easier, as I discover on my exit.

access_notes: The paved Mica Creek highway travels for 100 km north of Revelstoke. Downie Creek is one of the major drainages that connect to Revelstoke Lake (see Columbia River). The tree is located a few km up the Bigmouth Creek FSR, where it forks down to BMX bridge.
tree_site_notes: With active logging going on all around you, and recently logged blocks visible in every direction, it is amazing this grove of trees is still standing. Luckily, and perhaps because of riparian setback requirements this grove of big trees is nestled in beside Bigmouth Creek.

access_notes: The Big Bend Highway heads north from Highway 1 at Donald. The Giant Cedars Rec. Site is on the left side of the gravel road, and is well signed.
tree_site_notes: Located in the Help Creek floodplain the Giant Cedars line the trail through this very wet site. The sampled tree had its roots extending right into the creek.

access_notes: Following Mt. Fernie Park Rd. from Highway 3 to Island Lakes 2nd parking lot is where the trailhead to the Od Growth Trail begins.
tree_site_notes: Venturing off of the trail to a floodplain bench above Lizard Creek this massive tree stands in a meadow environment of Cow Parsnip and Devils club

access_notes: The Wap FSR extends from Three Valley Gap to Lumby. A spur referred to as Bottoms Rd. accesses this beautiful setting, where a plentiful grove of big cedars and hemlocks reside in a large seepage area above the lakes.
tree_site_notes: A luxuriant green surrounds you as you enter into this very boggy site, where big trees are nurtured by just the right stuff.

access_notes: Porto Rico Road for 800 m. Small pull-out just after bridge crossing the Salmo River. Exceptional gathering of big cedars, hemlocks, cottonwoods, and a couple grand firs, squeezed between the road and the river.
tree_site_notes: Very old tree with heavy crenelated bark, that could be mistaken for a cottonwood or hemlock. Beautiful very tall tree, with widely spreading branches.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  Drive to the Horseshoe Slough Trail trailhead in Richmond, at the South end of Shell Road. Hike South, stopping when the trail bends East. The tree will be visible from here. Bushwhack, minding the blackberry, South towards the tree and the slough. Cross the slough and arrive at the tree.
tree_site_notes: Twin-stem cottonwood, possibly at one point two separate trees, now fused together, splitting about 2.5m from the base. Massive English ivy infestation, covering virtually 100% of the tree, likely contributing to recent loss of limbs. Large bird nest.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see the current #1 Sitka spruce tree on your right. Park here and admire that tree before heading into the forest on the opposite side of the road (choose your own adventure as to how to get in there). Use GPS coordinates to track down the tree. An alternate route would be to bushwhack in off of Palmerston Main.
tree_site_notes: This spruce is truly out of this world! It must have grown over top of something a long time ago, creating this massive, burly, rootball base that if you measure it there, would be 4.7m wide. We measured it around the narrower trunk above. There is a noteable 'knuckle' window that sticks out off the side and reconnects with the tree creating a window. So strange!! Really one of the coolest trees either of us had ever seen before.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see the current #1 Sitka spruce tree on your right. Park here and admire that tree before heading into the forest on the opposite side of the road (choose your own adventure as to how to get in there). Use GPS coordinates to track down the tree.
tree_site_notes: An amazing spruce tree growing on the dividing line of dark, dreary second-growth and lush, epic old-growth. The tree's base and trunk have unique spiral shape and there is a hobbit hole on oneside providing space for an intrepid tree traveller to sit and ponder life's big questions. Well worth a visit!
A big, beautiful cedar with lovely coloured bark that swirls around. The tree has a hole that you can crawl right through at the base!
A giant cedar with whiteish bark. Looks like it's been around for awhile. Will probably be around for a long time still!
A cedar covered in small burls. Looks like a witches nose!
A massive cedar with a bear den.
A solid cedar growing in a lush patch of ferns.
A solid cedar growing in a lush patch of ferns.
Monumental redcedar with an active bear den. A really special tree and spot.
An towering cedar that soars skyward. Standing here feels like you're in the redwoods of California. This might be where all the fairys live.
A twisted redcedar that looks like a piece of red licorice!

A super giant cedar that makes you stop and say 'WOW'! This one really stands out and with the other big trees around it, makes for an amazing experience. A full sized Hemlock is also growing out of the trunk.
A super hefty cedar growing in a small creek ravine. A wall of wood!

access_notes: Take a boat to Vernon Bay in Barkley Sound, find a beach to land on, bushwhack into the forest. Dense terrain!!
Boat access to the shore then bushwhack in.
tree_site_notes: A beast of a cedar growing on a bench at the top of a rise.

access_notes: Take Gordon Main to Hemmingson Main then TR11 to the top of the mountain. This road is steep and sketchy. Alternatively, hike from the base of the mountain from Edinburgh Mainline before you get to Big Lonely Doug. This is a trek but doable.
tree_site_notes: A nice Douglas-fir within an approved cutblock on the backside of Edinburgh Moutain.

access_notes: Take Gordon Main to Ediburgh Main then walk ED39 spur road on left (old). Bushwhack up through overgrown clearcut (this sucks) until you get into a patch of old-growth with a few scattered giants.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful cedar in a remnant patch of old-growth on Edinburgh Moutain. A great place to have a nap after climbing down the mountain.
A scragly old cedar within an approved cutblock.
A big beautiful spruce that was spared logging in the 90's but now within an approved cutblock
A giant solid cedar that is now within an approved cutblock.

access_notes: This place is out there! Hike down off of Side Bay Main through second-growth and find a way to cross the Keith River  then bushwhack through the epic and beautiful old-growth using the GPS point as a guide.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful Sitka spruce tree growing in a Wildlife Habitat Area along the Keith River near Side Bay. Legend has it loggers refused to cut down this patch of forest given it's impressive nature while the entire surrounding areas were clearcut in the 1980's. Today an island of old-growth exists here. Impressive Sitka spruce trees abound in this grove, which is braided by a network of clear streams and wildlife trails. Still more to explore!

access_notes: This place is out there! Hike down off of Side Bay Main through second-growth and find a way to cross the Keith River  then bushwhack through the epic and beautiful old-growth using the GPS point as a guide.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful Sitka spruce tree growing in a Wildlife Habitat Area along the Keith River near Side Bay. Legend has it loggers refused to cut down this patch of forest given it's impressive nature while the entire surrounding areas were clearcut in the 1980's. Today an island of old-growth exists here. Impressive Sitka spruce trees abound in this grove, which is braided by a network of clear streams and wildlife trails. Still more to explore!

access_notes: Hike the Spruce Bay Recreation Trail from the camping area. This tree is slightly off trail towards the back end of the loop.
tree_site_notes: A towering Sitka spruce that is one among many along the Spruce Bay Trail. This trail is like a slice of Carmanah on the north island. The stumps in the second-growth nearby tell a heartbreaking story of trees of almost unimanginable proportions and densities, sadly gone forever. The Spruce Bay Trail is a glimpse into that lost world.

access_notes: A short bushwhack off of San Joseph Main through some wet and bushy terrain.
tree_site_notes: A towering Sitka spruce with two branches shooting upwards off its side like someone putting there arms up in the air!

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see the current #1 Sitka spruce tree on your right. Park here and admire that tree before walking further down the road. You will see a ribbon of trees on the left combing close to the road, parallel this towards the back edge of the clearing where you will find this tree.
tree_site_notes: A big ole' Sitka with some junk in its trunk! Big Girtha is just one of many massive spruce trees found in this exceptional zone - possibly the highest concentrations of giant Sitka's that we know of, largely (we think) due to the limestone substrate they grow on.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg get to NE Main and start travelling down Quatsino Sound. Carry onto SE Koprino Main then onto Hathaway Main then Michelson Main. Use GPS points to park close to the tree which will be on the left side of the road through a bit of a swampy section. Not super far but gumboots might help. You can see the big top from the road.
tree_site_notes: A beast of a spruce tree with a big burl at the base. This tree has a commanding presence when standing before it! Thankfully it's protected by an OGMA and WHA. There are other large spruce trees in the area. Worth more exploring in the dry season.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg get to NE Main and start travelling down Quatsino Sound. Carry onto SE Koprino Main then onto Hathaway Main then Michelson Main. Use GPS points to park close to the tree which will be on the left side of the road through a bit of a swampy section. Not super far but gumboots might help. You can see the big top from the road.
tree_site_notes: A nice big spruce in a nice forest. Thankfully it's protected by an OGMA and WHA. There is an amazing double-headed spruce across the road growing unprotected and well worth a look!

access_notes: Starting from Holberg get to NE Main and start travelling down Quatsino Sound. Carry onto SE Koprino Main then onto Hathaway Main then Michelson Main then Q Main line nearly to the end. This is a massive journey. Only worth it if you're already down this far.
tree_site_notes: A large Sitka spruce growing tall and straight like a Roman pillar.

access_notes: Take FSR's from Powell River to point closest to GPS and hike in through the second-growth.
tree_site_notes: The largest cedar in a stunning pocket of old-growth at the base of a towering cliff in the Eldred River Valley.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see tree BC BigTree # 411"San Jo's Smiley" on your right. Park here and admire that tree before hiking into the woods behind it and bushwhacking on an angle towards your left through some tricky log jams. This tree is on the edge of the next clearing you arrive at.
tree_site_notes: This is an incredibly impressive Sitka spruce tree with a gigantic columnar trunk that towers into the sky. The sheer volume is staggering. The tree has a broken top but seems to be healthy otherwise. The forest for the most part around it was logged in 2012, exposing one side to the elements. Other giants exist nearby. Certainly not a cheater tree, this one earns all it's wow factor on honest terms. A must see!!

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main roughly 10km towards the coast where you will take a spur road on your left (no name known). Stay on the main spur and after a short while the tree will be up a small rise on your left. You can't miss it.
tree_site_notes:
This cedar is absolutely enormous. It's huge, riveted trunk looks like the chest of a humpback whale. A number of large limbs then burst skyward, creating healthy and bushy crown. Unfortunately, however, like Big Lonely Doug, it stands alone in a clearcut from 2019. It's likely that its health will suffer now that the forest is gone around it. After surviving for many, many centuries, only time will tell if it will make it to the end of the next one.

*There is a notable spiral cedar within viewing distance of this one and another impressive lone cedar a bit further up the road as well.

access_notes: Tree is located at 782 Smith Road, Bowen Island, BC V0N-1G2. Take the ferry to Bowen Island. Continue onto Bowen Island Trunk Road. Turn right onto Mt. Gardner Road, continuing straight onto Woods Road. Turn right onto Smith Road. Continue onto the publicly accessible portion of the Xenia Centre's property. Signage will indicate where the Opa tree is (lefthand side of road). Beyond the Opa tree on this road is not open to the public. Please respect the Centre's instructions.
tree_site_notes: Tree is publicly accessible and in a viewing area with a couple benches immediatley beside the road. It appears to be healthy. The top broke off at some point in the past, but new leaders have taken its place.
